effective_dosage: 5 mL of lemon juice administered once per phase (two phases total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of lemon juice versus gentian violet for treating oral thrush in HIV/AIDS patients.
results_summary: Lemon juice showed better results than gentian violet in treating oral thrush among HIV-positive patients who completed the trial (p<0.02). The study validated its use for oral candidiasis in this population.
population_specificity: HIV-positive patients diagnosed with oral thrush.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if lemon juice could serve as an alternative to potassium citrate for treating urinary calcium stones in patients with hypocitraturia.
results_summary: Lemon juice significantly increased urinary citrate levels (2.5-fold) and reduced urinary calcium levels, comparable to potassium citrate. Dietary recommendations also improved treatment effectiveness.
population_specificity: 30 patients with hypocitraturic urinary calcium stones.
effective_dosage: 60 mEq/day (approximately 85 cc/day) of fresh lemon juice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the frequency of lemon juice usage among hypertensive patients in northern Turkey and highlight the need for clinical studies on its effects on blood pressure.
results_summary: The study found that 40% of hypertensive patients in the region consumed lemon juice as an alternative therapy, but no direct efficacy data on blood pressure reduction was provided. The abstract emphasizes the need for further clinical studies to assess lemon juice's impact on hypertension.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients in a local region of northern Turkey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the citric acid content of various fruit juices, including lemon juice, to assess their potential utility in nutrition therapy for calcium urolithiasis, particularly in patients with hypocitraturia.
results_summary: Lemon juice and lime juice were found to be rich sources of citric acid, with concentrations of 1.44 and 1.38 g/oz, respectively. Commercially available lemonade and other juice products had significantly lower citric acid content, ranging from 0.03 to 0.22 g/oz.
population_specificity: Patients with calcium urolithiasis, especially those with hypocitraturia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study measured citric acid content per ounce).
study_duration: Not specified (study was a single measurement analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of lemon juice and lemon dressing as natural preservatives in reducing Salmonella Typhimurium contamination in stuffed mussels.
results_summary: Lemon juice and lemon dressing caused slight reductions in Salmonella Typhimurium levels in stuffed mussels, with greater reductions observed at higher inoculum levels and longer exposure times (up to 15 minutes). However, the treatments were insufficient to fully prevent Salmonella outbreaks.
population_specificity: Stuffed mussels artificially contaminated with Salmonella Typhimurium.
effective_dosage: Fresh lemon juice and lemon dressing applied for 0, 5, and 15 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the bacteriostatic and bactericidal effects of lemon juice, combined with olive oil and oregano, on inoculated pathogens and autochthonous flora in Mediterranean gilt-head seabream.
results_summary: The treatment inhibited Staphylococcus aureus and Salmonella enteritidis, as well as autochthonous flora, with Brochothrix thermosphacta and pseudomonads dominating under modified atmosphere and air storage, respectively. Shewanella putrefaciens was notably suppressed.
population_specificity: Mediterranean gilt-head seabream (Sparus aurata)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of lemon juice, vinegar, and their combination in reducing Salmonella typhimurium counts on carrots.
results_summary: Lemon juice and vinegar alone significantly reduced Salmonella counts (0.79-3.95 and 1.57-3.58 log cfu/g, respectively), while their combination eliminated the pathogen to undetectable levels after 30 minutes.
population_specificity: Carrot samples inoculated with Salmonella typhimurium.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate lemon juice's biocidal activity against Vibrio cholerae in drinking water, particularly in areas lacking water treatment facilities.
results_summary: Lemon juice effectively destroyed Vibrio cholerae in water, but its efficacy decreased in highly alkaline water. A 2% concentration of lemon juice was sufficient to eliminate the bacteria in water with alkalinity equivalent to 200 mg CaCO3 per liter after 30 minutes of exposure.
population_specificity: Water samples from rural and urban areas in Buenos Aires Province, Argentina, with varying alkalinity and hardness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lemon juice administration could prevent calcium oxalate urolithiasis in rats induced by ethylene glycol and ammonium chloride.
results_summary: Lemon juice inhibited the EG/AC-induced increase in kidney calcium levels and prevented calcium oxalate crystal deposits, with 100% and 75% concentrations showing complete protection.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats
effective_dosage: 100%, 75%, or 50% lemon juice (6 µL solution/g body weight, administered by gavage)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the behavioral, cognitive, psychological, and physiological effects of 56 days of lemon verbena extract (LVE) supplementation in children exhibiting sub-clinical ADHD symptoms.
results_summary: LVE supplementation led to greater subjective fatigue but no cognitive impairments, lower depression symptoms by day 56, and a near-significant reduction in parent-reported hyperactive/impulsive behavior. Exploratory analyses suggested additional cognitive and mood benefits.
population_specificity: Healthy children aged 8-17 years exhibiting sub-clinical ADHD symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether squirting lemon juice into an infant's mouth could effectively eliminate chronic, life-threatening rumination.
results_summary: The study found that squirting lemon juice into the infant's mouth eliminated rumination, and a brief suspension of therapy demonstrated its crucial role. However, the study's single-case design limits broader claims about effectiveness.
population_specificity: A six-month-old infant with chronic, life-threatening rumination.
effective_dosage: A small amount (specific quantity not stated), administered whenever rumination or its precursors were detected.
study_duration: The intervention duration is not explicitly stated, but the study lasted long enough to observe effects and a brief suspension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant and anti-proliferation effects of Aloysia citrodora (Lemon Verbena) extracts.
results_summary: The ethyl acetate extract significantly reduced tumor size (57.97%) and resulted in undetected tumors (44.44%) in treated mice, while the ethanol extract showed potent radical scavenging effects. The study demonstrated promising cytotoxic and antioxidant activities but noted the need for further investigation into the extract's chemical composition.
population_specificity: Balb/C mice inoculated with tumor cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the destructive effect and mode of action of lemon verbena essential oil on Pseudosciaena D4 cells, focusing on its impact on cell integrity and biomembrane formation.
results_summary: Lemon verbena essential oil disrupted Pseudosciaena D4 cell integrity, inhibited extracellular polysaccharide secretion, and caused cell wall destruction, leading to cell death. Higher concentrations of the oil showed increased inhibition rates and reduced extracellular polysaccharide content.
population_specificity: Pseudosciaena D4 cells (a specific bacterial strain).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the synergistic effects of a combination of lemon verbena and hibiscus-flower extracts (Metabolaid®) on obesity and its complications in high-fat-diet-induced obese mice.
results_summary: The study found that Metabolaid® reduced body weight, white adipose tissue, and liver weight, improved lipid profiles, glucose levels, and thermogenesis, and modulated appetite-regulating hormones and inflammatory markers. It also influenced adipogenesis and thermogenesis-related gene expression.
population_specificity: High-fat-diet-induced obese mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of low-pressure cold plasma (LPCP) treatments on the essential oil content and composition of lemon verbena leaves.
results_summary: The study found that increasing LPCP treatment duration reduced essential oil content from 1.2% to 0.9% (v/w). LPCP-treated leaves showed higher levels of monoterpene hydrocarbons and oxygenated sesquiterpenes, while untreated leaves had higher oxygenated monoterpenes (e.g., citral).
population_specificity: Lemon verbena leaves (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with Planox® lemon verbena extract (LVE) could mitigate muscle damage, inflammation, and oxidative stress following exhaustive exercise.
results_summary: LVE supplementation significantly increased GPx activity, reduced CK, IL-6, 8-OHdG levels, and alleviated muscle pain post-exercise, though it did not significantly affect strength recovery. The study concluded that LVE is a safe and effective natural extract for reducing exercise-induced muscle damage and soreness.
population_specificity: 30 males and 30 females, gender-balanced.
study_duration: Supplementation began 10 days before exhaustive exercise and continued until all tests were completed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Aloysia citriodora (Lemon Verbena) in improving sleep quality and reducing insomnia symptoms in patients with insomnia.
results_summary: The study found that Lemon Verbena significantly improved sleep quality (measured by PSQI) and reduced insomnia severity (measured by ISI) compared to placebo after 4 weeks of treatment, with improvements also observed at 2 weeks.
population_specificity: 100 patients with insomnia, randomly divided into intervention and placebo groups.
effective_dosage: 10 cc of syrup (containing 1.66 mg essential oil and 3.22 mg flavonoids per 10 ml) taken once daily before bedtime.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a polyphenolic extract combination of Lippia citriodora (Lemon Verbena) and Hibiscus sabdariffa could improve anthropometric measurements, blood pressure, and appetite biomarkers in overweight subjects.
results_summary: The study found improvements in anthropometric measurements, reduced blood pressure and heart rate, and a positive shift in overall health perception. The supplement also increased anorexigenic hormones (GLP-1) and decreased orexigenic hormones (ghrelin).
population_specificity: 54 overweight subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether lemon verbena aqueous extract, verbascoside, and caffeine could enhance the antimicrobial effects of gentamicin against Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli strains.
results_summary: Lemon verbena extract, verbascoside, and caffeine alone showed no inhibitory effects on bacterial strains but reduced the MIC of gentamicin against resistant strains and clinical isolates, with verbascoside-gentamicin combination showing synergistic effects.
population_specificity: Standard and clinical isolates of Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli.
interactions: Enhanced gentamicin's antimicrobial action (synergistic effect observed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of lemon verbena powder and vitamin C on performance and immunity in broiler chickens under heat stress.
results_summary: Dietary supplementation with 1.0% lemon verbena improved weight gain, feed intake, and feed conversion ratio, reduced LDL levels, and enhanced immune parameters such as glutathione peroxidase activity and heterophil-to-lymphocyte ratio.
population_specificity: Male Ross 308 broiler chickens under heat stress conditions.
effective_dosage: 0.5% and 1.0% lemon verbena powder in diet; 250 mg/kg vitamin C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a proprietary lemon verbena extract (Recoverben®) on muscle strength and recovery after exhaustive exercise compared to a placebo.
results_summary: Participants taking lemon verbena extract experienced less muscle damage, faster recovery, significantly less exercise-related loss of muscle strength, and reduced movement-induced pain compared to placebo. However, creatine kinase and IL-6 levels did not significantly differ between groups.
population_specificity: 44 healthy males and females aged 22-50 who were active in sports.
effective_dosage: 400 mg lemon verbena extract once daily.
study_duration: 15 days (10 days pre-exercise, 1 day during, and 4 days post-exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of lemon verbena supplementation on pro- and anti-inflammatory serum biomarkers in patients with different clinical subtypes of multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: Lemon verbena supplementation significantly reduced C-reactive protein levels in secondary progressive MS patients compared to placebo. Other cytokine markers were studied, but specific results beyond C-reactive protein were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 30 participants with relapsing-remitting (n=10), primary progressive (n=5), and secondary progressive (n=15) multiple sclerosis.
effective_dosage: 10% w/w verbascoside (exact dosage amount not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the in-vivo anti-Trypanosoma cruzi activity of Aloysia triphylla (lemon verbena) essential oil in mice.
results_summary: Lemon verbena essential oil significantly reduced parasitemia by 85.4% at 250 mg/kg, decreased amastigotes and inflammatory infiltrates in the heart, and lowered creatine kinase-MB plasma levels by day 28 post-infection.
population_specificity: Mice infected with Trypanosoma cruzi.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of a supplement containing lemon verbena extract and omega-3 fatty acids as an alternative treatment for joint pain and dysfunction.
results_summary: The supplement significantly reduced pain and stiffness (53% reduction in WOMAC scores, 78% in Lequesne's scores) and improved joint function after 9 weeks, with effects becoming statistically significant by weeks 3-4. Lemon verbena also demonstrated strong antioxidant properties in lab tests.
population_specificity: 45 subjects with joint pain discomfort.
effective_dosage: Standardized lemon verbena extract (14% verbascoside, w/w) combined with fish oil omega-3 fatty acids (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a lemon verbena-based dietary supplement could help individuals manage stress and improve sleep quality.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of lemon verbena.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of ethanolic extract of Lemon Verbena in treating Staphylococcus aureus skin infections in an animal model.
results_summary: The study found that Lemon Verbena ointment reduced wound appearance rates (46.2% vs. 84.2% in untreated controls) and showed better recovery compared to untreated groups, though necrotic wounds were more common in the ointment group. Injection of Lemon Verbena solution also showed improvement (23.1% lesion persistence vs. 77.7% in controls).
population_specificity: 63 laboratory mice (20-30 g) with induced Staphylococcus aureus skin infections.
effective_dosage: Not specified (ointment and injection forms used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether moderate antioxidant supplementation with lemon verbena extract could protect against oxidative damage and muscular tissue damage during chronic running exercise without inhibiting cellular adaptation.
results_summary: Lemon verbena supplementation reduced oxidative damage in neutrophils, decreased signs of muscular damage, and maintained cellular adaptation to exercise without blocking the antioxidant response. It also lowered myeloperoxidase activity and protected muscular tissue, as indicated by stable or reduced serum transaminases.
population_specificity: Healthy male volunteers following a 90-minute running eccentric exercise protocol.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the cause of stunted, chlorotic, and defoliated lentils in eastern Washington and Idaho, focusing on potential fungal and oomycete pathogens.
results_summary: The study found that Pythium irregulare caused root rot, stunting, and chlorosis in lentils, with cv. Mason being more affected than cv. Brewer. The pathogen was confirmed through greenhouse testing and DNA sequencing.
population_specificity: Lentil plants (Lens culinaris Medik.), specifically cvs. Mason and Brewer, in eastern Washington and Idaho.
effective_dosage: Inoculum added at 500 CFU/g of soil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of heat treatment, mineral and vitamin supplementation, and olive oil on the bioavailability of protein and calcium in lentils for growing rats.
results_summary: Heating lentils reduced trypsin inhibitor activity, phytate, and tannin content but did not improve protein intake or digestive use. Supplementation with minerals, vitamins, and olive oil significantly improved food intake and nutritive use of nitrogen and calcium, with the best results seen in raw lentils supplemented with a premix.
population_specificity: Growing rats
effective_dosage: 4% olive oil supplementation, mineral and vitamin premix (specific amounts not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cardioprotective mechanisms of lentils and other plant-based seeds in reducing cardiovascular disease risk.
results_summary: The study found that lentils and similar seeds minimize classical cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., obesity, hypertension, dyslipidemia) and provide beneficial compounds (e.g., n-3 fatty acids, isoflavones, arginine) that improve oxidant status, vascular reactivity, and myocardial stability. A shift away from these foods may increase cardiovascular risk.
population_specificity: General population, with emphasis on Asian diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to purify and characterize IgE-binding proteins from boiled lentil extracts to identify allergens responsible for pediatric allergic reactions in the Mediterranean area.
results_summary: The study identified two types of allergens in boiled lentils: 12-16 kd gamma-vicilin subunits (Len c 1) and a 66 kd seed-specific biotinylated protein (Len c 2), which were recognized by 68% and 41% of allergic patients' sera, respectively, and showed significant IgE-binding inhibition.
population_specificity: Pediatric allergic patients in the Mediterranean area.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to purify and characterize alpha-amylase from lentils germinated for 6 days, studying its enzymatic properties and stability.
results_summary: The study successfully purified alpha-amylase from lentils, identifying its optimal pH (5.4), activation energy (5.8 kcal/mol), and molecular weight (43,000). The enzyme showed stability under specific pH and temperature conditions, with activity affected by calcium and mercuric ions.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on lentil cotyledons).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the clinical and epidemiological characteristics of patients undergoing oral food challenges for suspected food allergies, including lentils.
results_summary: Among 215 oral challenges, 2 were positive for legumes (peanuts and lentils), indicating a low but present allergic response to lentils in the studied population.
population_specificity: Patients (mostly children, 69%) evaluated for suspected food allergies in a Colombian reference center from 2011 to 2018.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the beneficial effects of plant-based diets, including lentils, on inflammatory skin diseases and healthy skin.
results_summary: The study found that plant-based diets, which include lentils, may have beneficial effects on skin health, particularly in inflammatory skin diseases, potentially mediated through the gut microbiome.
population_specificity: General human population (no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the glycemic index (GI) and glycemic response of lentils compared to other traditional Greek mixed meals.
results_summary: Lentils had the lowest GI (27 ± 5) among the tested meals, with the lowest peak blood glucose values, indicating a favorable glycemic response. Subjective appetite ratings were also assessed, though specific results for lentils were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Twelve healthy, fasting individuals.
effective_dosage: 25 g available carbohydrate per test meal.
study_duration: Blood glucose samples were collected over 120 minutes post-consumption.

study_goal: To determine the acceptability of recipes prepared with biofortified lentils compared to control varieties among young children and their breastfeeding mothers.
results_summary: Recipes with biofortified lentils were consumed readily and rated as highly acceptable, with no significant differences observed between biofortified and control varieties.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-24 months and their breastfeeding mothers (n = 52 pairs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lentil-based meals improve glycemic control and satiety compared to meat-based meals in metabolically at-risk adults, while also assessing gastrointestinal symptom severity.
results_summary: The study found that lentil consumption led to dose-dependent reductions in hepatic insulin resistance and mild gastrointestinal symptoms, with most participants reporting no to mild GI discomfort. Satiety improvements were also observed, though specific details were less emphasized.
population_specificity: Adults with increased waist circumference (male > 40 inches, female > 35 inches), nondiabetic, and metabolically at-risk.
effective_dosage: 0 g (control), 300 g (moderate), or 600 g (high) of cooked green lentils per prepared midday meal, 5 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if child-centered nutrition phrases (CCNP) combined with repeated exposure (RE) improved children's willingness to try, liking, and consumption of lentils compared to RE alone.
results_summary: Children showed greater consumption of lentils when exposed to CCNP + RE compared to RE alone at follow-up assessment, indicating a positive effect of the intervention on lentil consumption.
population_specificity: Children aged 3-6 years old, predominantly white (67%), from middle-income homes, with parents having some higher education.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential health benefits of polyphenols in lentils, focusing on their antioxidant properties and role in preventing chronic diseases.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that dietary polyphenols in lentils may protect against chronic diseases induced by oxidative stress, with their health effects linked to human consumption and bioavailability.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the association between personal/sociodemographic factors, dietary intake of other food groups, and the consumption of pulses (including lentils) in first-year university students.
results_summary: The study found that 75.8% of students had inadequate pulse consumption (≤2 times/week). Living outside the family home (e.g., in student residences or rentals) decreased compliance with pulse consumption recommendations. No specific focus group for intervention was identified, suggesting broad policies are needed to improve consumption.
population_specificity: First-year university students from eleven Spanish universities (n=9862).
study_duration: Data collected during the 2011-2018 academic years (cross-sectional analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update and expand the understanding of selenium's role in mitigating arsenic and cadmium toxicity, including selenium derived from lentils.
results_summary: The study found that selenium, including from lentils, can reduce arsenic- and cadmium-mediated toxicity in various organs through sequestration into inert complexes, activation of antioxidant enzymes, and possibly enhancing arsenic methylation. New evidence suggests selenium may also reduce toxicity via the Nrf2 pathway.
population_specificity: Animal models and cell culture studies (no specific human population mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate lentils as an emerging allergen source and assess their potential to cause allergic reactions, including severe and exercise-induced anaphylaxis.
results_summary: Lentils were identified as a potentially important allergen source, capable of causing mild-to-severe allergic reactions, including food-dependent exercise-induced anaphylaxis. Cross-reactivity with other legumes, such as peanut and lupine, was noted as a significant concern.
population_specificity: Individuals with legume allergies or those consuming plant-based diets.
interactions: Cross-reactivity with other legumes (e.g., peanut, lupine) mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current knowledge on GABA occurrence in pulses, focusing on mechanisms to increase GABA levels and analytical methods for its extraction and estimation.
results_summary: The study highlights that pulses, including lentils, contain GABA, which has health benefits such as anti-diabetic and hypotensive effects, and that GABA levels can be increased through processes like enzymatic treatment, gaseous treatment, and fermentation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health focus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-selenium lentils could improve health outcomes by reducing arsenic toxicity in arsenic-exposed individuals.
results_summary: The study is planned to assess arsenic excretion, deposition, and morbidity outcomes, but results are not yet available as it is a proposed clinical trial. Secondary outcomes include antioxidant status, lipid profile, lung inflammation, and blood pressure.
population_specificity: Arsenic-exposed Bangladeshi villagers (≥14 years) with household tube well arsenic concentration ≥100 ppb.

study_goal: To assess the efficacy of small non-financial incentives (raw lentils and metal plates) on improving immunisation rates in children aged 1-3 compared to improving service reliability alone.
results_summary: The study found that providing small incentives (raw lentils and metal plates) alongside reliable immunisation services significantly increased full immunisation rates (39%) compared to reliable services alone (18%) or no intervention (6%). The incentives were more cost-effective and also positively impacted neighboring areas.
population_specificity: 1640 children aged 1-3 in rural Rajasthan, India.
effective_dosage: Raw lentils and metal plates provided upon completed immunisation (specific quantity not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of bacteriophage-based biocontrol to reduce Acidovorax valerianellae contamination in lettuce seeds and improve germination rates.
results_summary: The study found that phage treatment reduced bacterial concentration by 87% on artificially infested seeds, increasing germination rates from 58.9% to 93.3%. Additionally, phage-treated seedlings showed improved vigor compared to infected ones, though lipopolysaccharides in phage suspensions negatively impacted root development.
population_specificity: Lamb's lettuce (Valerianella locusta) seeds and seedlings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether blending lentils or using α-galactosidase affects postprandial appetite and blood glucose responses compared to whole lentils.
results_summary: Blended lentils increased appetite (~6%) compared to whole lentils but did not affect glycemic response. α-Galactosidase had no significant impact on appetite or glucose levels. Both blended and whole lentils showed minimal impact on appetite without increasing glycemic response.
population_specificity: 12 men and women (BMI 23.3 ± 3.1; aged 28 ± 10 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (meals contained whole or blended lentils; α-galactosidase or placebo capsules).
study_duration: 3- to 5-day washout periods between test days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the allelopathic effects of horseradish root extract (HRE) on onion root growth and cell cycle dynamics.
results_summary: Higher HRE concentrations significantly reduced onion root growth and disrupted cell cycle phases, with increased dead tissue ratios at higher doses. ROS accumulation decreased as HRE concentration increased.
population_specificity: Onion root tips (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the growth-promoting effects of Pseudomonas sp. 31-12 when incorporated into lettuce seed pelleting, including its impact on germination, root and shoot growth, and population stability.
results_summary: Pseudomonas sp. 31-12 significantly increased leaf fresh mass in lettuce and maintained stable populations on roots, demonstrating growth promotion in both laboratory and greenhouse settings. The bacterial population on pelleted seeds decreased slightly after storage but remained effective in promoting growth.
population_specificity: Green oak lettuce (Lactuca sativa L.) seeds and plants.
effective_dosage: Not specified (bacterial population measured as cfu/seed or cfu/g root dry mass).
study_duration: 3 months storage at 4°C; greenhouse growth assessed at 15 and 30 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of saturated salt accelerated aging (SSAA) on seed vigor and resilience in two lettuce cultivars ('Muir' and 'Bauer') using projected canopy size (PCS) as a predictor of shoot dry weight.
results_summary: The study found that 'Muir' exhibited consistent PCS values across SSAA treatments, while 'Bauer' showed declines after prolonged aging. Germination rates dropped significantly after 48 and 72 h of SSAA, and PCS strongly predicted shoot dry weight (R2 = 0.93).
population_specificity: Seeds of two lettuce cultivars ('Muir' and 'Bauer').
effective_dosage: 40 g/100 mL of NaCl solution at 41 °C for 24, 48, and 72 h.
study_duration: Up to 72 hours of SSAA treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of lettuce seed syrup in improving sleep quality in breast cancer patients with insomnia or sleep disorders.
results_summary: Lettuce seed syrup significantly reduced the total PSQI score and improved specific sleep parameters (quality, duration, efficacy, and disturbance) compared to placebo. The results suggest it may enhance self-reported sleep quality in this population.
population_specificity: Adult breast cancer patients with insomnia or sleep disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a hands-on laboratory activity in teaching students about allelopathy and the glucosinolate-myrosinase system using lettuce seed germination and root length measurements.
results_summary: The study found that the laboratory activity significantly improved students' understanding of allelopathy and the glucosinolate-myrosinase system, as evidenced by higher post-laboratory quiz scores (6.56 vs. 3.14 out of 10). Additionally, students reported improved self-efficacy and found the activity engaging and educational.
population_specificity: Undergraduate students (n = 76) participating in a laboratory activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms of lettuce seed germination and thermoinhibition, focusing on proteomic changes and the role of the mevalonate (MVA) pathway in these processes.
results_summary: The study identified 108 protein spots with significant abundance changes during germination, linking methionine metabolism, ethylene production, and the MVA pathway to germination and thermoinhibition. Inhibition of the MVA pathway delayed germination and increased sensitivity to abscisic acid, while cytokinins reversed these effects.
population_specificity: Lettuce seeds (Lactuca sativa 'Jianyexianfeng No. 1')

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the sedative and hypnotic effects of L. sativa seed oil in patients suffering from insomnia.
results_summary: L. sativa seed oil significantly improved anxiety and sleep scores compared to placebo, with no reported side effects at the given dosage. The study concluded it could be a safe treatment for mild-to-moderate anxiety and sleep difficulties.
population_specificity: Sixty patients with insomnia, with or without anxiety.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the effects of salicylhydroxamic acid (SHAM) and cyanide (CN) on stimulating dark germination in lettuce seeds (Lactuca sativa L.).
results_summary: SHAM and CN combined greatly enhanced dark germination, with potentiation occurring within the first 8 hours of hydration. SHAM alone nearly matched the potentiation effect but inhibited radicle elongation, reducing germination over 72 hours. Oxygen presence was critical for SHAM and SHAM + CN to stimulate germination.
population_specificity: Lettuce seeds (Lactuca sativa L.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether endogenous ethylene plays a role in alleviating thermoinhibition of lettuce seed germination at high temperatures when induced by treatments of GA(3), KIN, and CO(2).
results_summary: The study found that combinations of GA(3), KIN, and CO(2) significantly increased ethylene production and promoted lettuce seed germination at 32°C. Inhibition of ethylene synthesis or action reduced germination, which was reversed by exogenous ethylene, indicating endogenous ethylene is essential for thermoinhibition relief.
population_specificity: Lettuce seeds (Lactuca sativa L. cv Grand Rapids)
effective_dosage: GA(3) (0.5 millimolar), KIN (0.05 millimolar), CO(2) (10%), AVG (1 millimolar), 2,5-norbornadiene (0.25-2 milliliters per liter), exogenous ethylene (1-100 microliters per liter)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how gibberellic acid (GA(3)) and red light affect the germination rate and final percentage of lettuce seeds (Lactuca sativa L. cv. Grand Rapids).
results_summary: GA(3) treatment and red light illumination influenced the germination rate of lettuce seeds, with GA(3) also affecting the final germination percentage. The study found that early germination processes initiated by GA(3) or light could be halted by exposure to a nongerminative temperature (35 C), suggesting different biochemical mechanisms for light and GA(3) in germination.
population_specificity: Lettuce seeds (Lactuca sativa L. cv. Grand Rapids)
effective_dosage: GA(3) applied for 1 hour after 2 hours of imbibition

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how artificial electrostatic fields influence the germination of "Grand Rapids" lettuce seed and its interaction with red light exposure.
results_summary: A 2-minute exposure to electrostatic fields (75 V cm(-1)) increased germination by up to 10%, partially substituting for red light. Pre-irradiation treatment slightly repressed germination, while longer red irradiation periods negated electrostatic effects.
population_specificity: "Grand Rapids" lettuce seeds

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of ethylene on the germination of lettuce seeds, including its interaction with light and carbon dioxide.
results_summary: Ethylene increased germination in freshly imbibed lettuce seeds under red, far-red light, or darkness but had no effect on dormant seeds. Carbon dioxide did not clearly reverse ethylene-enhanced germination, and light doubled ethylene production independently of the phytochrome system.
population_specificity: Lettuce seeds (Lactuca sativa L. var. Grand Rapids)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how light and temperature treatments affect dark germination in light-requiring lettuce seeds.
results_summary: Cold treatment promoted dark germination at high temperatures, but far-red irradiation reversed this effect. Red light enhanced germination when followed by cold treatment, suggesting pre-existing active phytochrome interacts with a co-factor during imbibition.
population_specificity: Lettuce seeds (Lactuca sativa)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how heat treatments (35°C) and light exposure (far red or red) affect photodormancy and germination in Grand Rapids lettuce seeds.
results_summary: Short heat treatments (1-5 hours) significantly increased dark germination (16% to over 50%), while longer treatments reduced it to zero. Far red or red light after heat further enhanced dark germination, and thermodormancy delayed red-stimulated germination by 10+ hours.
population_specificity: Grand Rapids lettuce (Lactuca sativa L.) seeds.
study_duration: Variable, depending on heat treatment duration (1-5 hours or longer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinical relevance, biological implications, and therapeutic potential of LRRC15 in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC).
results_summary: The study found robust overexpression of LRRC15 in TNBC, inversely correlated with patient survival, and demonstrated that LRRC15 suppression inhibited TNBC cell proliferation, invasion, and migration by activating the ITGB1/FAK/PI3K signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) patients and cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of LGI1 encephalitis and assess the response to rituximab therapy.
results_summary: The study found that a 61-year-old patient with LGI1 encephalitis showed significant improvement in symptoms (cognitive decline, seizures, hyponatremia) after rituximab therapy. The abstract highlights the need for standardized treatment approaches due to limited comprehensive studies.
population_specificity: A 61-year-old Saudi retiree with LGI1 encephalitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective mechanisms of N-acetyl-L-leucine (NALL) in neurodegenerative diseases, particularly its effects on α-synuclein pathology and synaptic function in Parkinson's disease (PD) models.
results_summary: NALL upregulated lysosomal, mitochondrial, and synaptic proteins, reduced pathological pS129-alpha-synuclein, and improved synaptic function in PD patient-derived dopaminergic neurons and LRRK2 mutant mice. The effects were mediated through HTRA1 induction and parkin upregulation.
population_specificity: PD patient-derived dopaminergic neurons (GBA1 or LRRK2 mutations) and LRRK2R1441C knock-in mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to document a rare case of anti-LGI1 limbic encephalitis in a woman with newly diagnosed breast cancer, exploring its association and treatment outcomes.
results_summary: The patient exhibited cognitive impairment, epilepsy, and hyponatraemia, which improved after immunotherapy, corticosteroids, and tumor excision. This is the first well-documented case of anti-LGI1 encephalitis linked to breast cancer in a woman.
population_specificity: A woman with subacute amnestic syndrome, cognitive impairment, and early-stage breast cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop novel LRRK2 inhibitors targeting the G2019S mutation for treating Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, and other CNS disorders.
results_summary: The study identified a new class of indazole/azaindazole-substituted cyclopentapyrroles that selectively inhibit LRRK2 with the G2019S mutation, proposing their potential therapeutic use for CNS disorders.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on molecular targets rather than human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of leucine-rich α-2 glycoprotein 1 (LRG1) in vascular dysfunction during cancer growth and inflammatory complications after alloHSCT and CAR-T cell therapy.
results_summary: Elevated LRG1 levels were linked to cytokine release syndrome, neurotoxicity, and acute graft-versus-host disease (aGVHD). Genetic deletion of LRG1 reduced disease severity in preclinical models, improving vascular function and reducing inflammation-related complications.
population_specificity: Patients with cytokine release syndrome, immune effector cell-associated neurotoxicity syndrome after CAR-T-cell therapy, and acute graft-versus-host disease (aGVHD) after alloHSCT, as well as preclinical models of aGVHD, colitis, and paw edema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how heat treatment affects lettuce seed germination and whether gibberellic acid (GA) and other compounds (EBNU, EDNA) can overcome this inhibition.
results_summary: Heat treatment (30°-42°C) inhibited lettuce seed germination at 25°C, but GA reversed this effect. EBNU and EDNA enhanced GA's activity only when seeds were exposed to 30°-35°C for ≥72 hours, but these compounds did not affect natural or heat-induced dormancy.
population_specificity: Lettuce seeds (variety Grand Rapids)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between LUZP4-IgG seropositivity and paraneoplastic neurologic syndrome in a patient with testicular seminoma.
results_summary: The study identified LUZP4-IgG seropositivity in a patient with progressive tetraparesis and seminoma, suggesting a paraneoplastic neurologic syndrome. Aggressive immunotherapy led to clinical improvement, highlighting the role of specific biomarkers in guiding treatment.
population_specificity: A 51-year-old male with testicular seminoma and progressive neurologic symptoms.
